content.description:
This is more like 2.5 stars, but I'll round up. Its grade may be a little height-dependent. All the holds are bomber - if you're grabbing choss, you've got the wrong beta.

Start on the obvious rounded hold around head height with a couple of perfect foot edges, and follow the arete, topping out to the left at the tallest part of the overhung face. The crux is probably near the top, but it's hard to tell really - all the holds are good, and the moves are quite fun for the grade. Ascend the downclimb on the slabby face to your right to get a better perspective on some important holds.
content.protection: A single pad for the top section and a spotter to keep you out of the sage shrub at the base would be an ok idea.

content.description:
The only jugs are the start and the finish, which makes for a fun and careful series of movements. I kind of want to give it V3 - may be height-dependent.

Start with arms spread, with your left hand on a meaty, flakey undercling and your right hand paying lip service to a sloped edge with a good but optional separate thumb catch. Figure out those barn-door-prevention feet, then move up and left, topping out on either the decent lip directly above the start or the excellent jug behind the corner of the boulder. Try not to fall after moving off the starting undercling lest ye break your back (or at least severely bruise it) on the rock behind the tiny landing wash.
content.protection: Multiple pads are recommended, the potential fall is into a depressed area with a pretty mean looking rock directly behind it.
